RelationshipElement.name: Bonded To
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a bonded to for contexts

RelationshipElement.name: Arbitrarily separated from
RelationshipElement.description: When two or more context codes have been assigned to what is ultimately determined to be the same context

RelationshipElement.name: Broadly contemporary with
RelationshipElement.description: Contexts suspected to be contemporary but no direct physical relationship or evidence (i.e. adjacent buildings)

RelationshipElement.name: EarlierLater
RelationshipElement.description: Implements a Stratigraphically Immediately Earlier-Later for contexts.

ArchaeologicalElement.name: Context
ArchaeologicalElement.description: The physical result of any single action whether it leaves a positive or negative record within the stratigraphic sequence. (MoLAS 1994)

property.name: AreaCode
property.description: The excavation trench, designated by a letter code and assigned automatically by the module based on your selection when you log in.

property.name: Context ID
property.description: Every archaeological context (negative element (cut), deposit, structure, skeleton, artefact cluster) is given a unique 3 or 4 letter context code. Each trench is designated with a separate letter which starts the code, so it is immediately obvious to which trench a context belongs. For example context HAA belongs to Trench H, context MQP to Trench M etc. The contexts are labelled consecutively in alphabetical order using the letters following the trench letter. For Trench H the first context would be HAA, the second HAB, the third HAB and so on. In addition sets of letters can denote parts of trenches, buildings etc. E.g. HFs might denote contexts from a specific building. Burial context codes begin with the letter Z, followed by the trench letter. Hence burial ZHA is the first burial context from trench H. Check with the trench supervisor who will assign the context code from the central register.
property.formatString: Cxtx-$2-

property.name: Context Name
property.description: Enter a brief, clear name for the Context eg 'House A - west wall'

property.name: Grid X
property.description: The X coordinate on the SW corner of the context.

property.name: Grid Y

property.name: Location Note

lookup.term: {Other} Excavated by another method. Add details in Annotation field.

property.name: Horizon Boundary
property.description: Describe the boundary between this and the next context.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Doubtful} You are uncertain of whether you accurately excavated a boundary between deposits
{Ambiguous} You are uncertain as to whether there was a boundary between contexts.
{Merging} There is a distinction between the excavated context and earlier context(s) but the excavated contexts and the earlier contexts grade into each other
{Clear} The boundary with the earlier context(s) was very clearly defined during excavation.
{ArbitrarySpit} There is no meaningful boundary with an earlier context. The boundary has been artificially created by the excavation process.

property.name: Contamination
property.description: The extent to which the context has been contaminated.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Contaminated} Contaminated by later material eg by unidentified cut at time of initial excavation by large scale animal or root activity which were not isolated by excavation by excavation processes some annoying person mixed the material or stuff fell into deposit from the section.

{High_likelihood_high_amount_derived} It is very likely that significant amounts of earlier artifact and ecofact material has become incorporated in the deposit. For example; is this context a mud brick wall or other structure or building or structural debris or a deposit which has seen the redeposition of material excavated from cuts. These are all situations in which earlier material is likely to have been dug up and re-used (in the mud brick) or re-deposited (when digging out pits).
{Low_likelihood_low_amount_derived} You think there is little chance that very much earlier material has made it's way into this deposit.

{Primary_deposit} You are very sure that the deposit and all finds therein directly relate to activity within a specific period of time and there is thus minimal amounts of derived material and no contamination.

property.name: Context Type
property.description: Describe the context type by selecting an icon as defined below. When you have selected a context type you can proceed to open the "Fill in context type details" page. Note this page will not open unless you have selected a context type.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Negative_Element} Any Context which represents the removal of earlier deposit and thus forms a negative interface (cut) with another context, such as a cut for a pit, burial, ditch, wall foundation or robber trench.
{Deposit} Any Context with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
{Structure} Any Context consisting of deliberately constructed structural element, independent of a Negative Element (i.e. cut, such as a wall or a hearth).

property.name: Deposit Your Interpretation
property.description: Your interpretation of the likely function of the context.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Indeterminate} You are unable to make an assessment of possible function.
{Packing} Packing in a post hole for post material fulfilling a constructional purpose other than deliberate levelling deposits.
{Makeup_Levelling} Material laid down to level or raise an area for constructional purposes or other activities.
{Dump} Material probably dumped as a result of other activity e.g. material removed from cuts or other constructional or destructional activity.
{Midden} Distinct area of organic rubbish accumulation
{Burial} A fill or other deposit associated with a skeleton and forming part of a burial feature.
{Structural_Debris_Collapse} Material derived from collapse of a wall, roof or other structure
{Partly_naturally_derived} A deposit partly or wholly accumulating through natural sedimentary processes, such as water or wind deposition.

{Wholly_naturally_derived} All of the deposit accumulating through the deposition of natural sediments through geomorphological processes eg wind borne sediments water-laid natural sediments material flaking from cave and rock shelter walls.
{Erosional_products} Material deriving from the erosion of earlier archaeological sediments.
{Artifact_Cluster} A distinct concentration of artifacts or ecofacts. Make sure you record its xyz coordinates centre and edges.
{Ash_Charcoal} A deposit consisting largely of carbonized/charred plant material and/or ash

{Arbitrary} This applies to artificial contexts excavated for excavational convenience eg section cleaning material whose precise provenience is unclear. Does not include arbitrary spits or spatial units deliberately excavated for finer control of horizontal and vert

{Distinct_floor_contact} To be used for material that directly reflects the use of a surface or floor - artefact material on the surface perhaps thin deposits of occupation material. These contexts will be gridded into spatial units for closer control of artifact distributions.
{Animal_Plant} Deposit derived from plant or animal activity
{Other} Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

property.name: Soil Compaction Type
property.description: Describe the compaction of the sediments in the Context.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Friable} Deposit disintegrates into small particles under pressure.
{Crumbly} Deposit disintegrates into lumps under pressure.

property.name: Soil Compaction Description
property.description: Description of the compaction of soil including changes throughout the deposit. Eg "Varies from loose to compact."
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Soil Particle Sorting
property.description: Assessment of the frequency with which particles of the same size occur.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Moderately_sorted} Particles are mostly the same size and evenly distributed but there are some larger particles.
{Poorly_sorted} Particles are different sizes and unevenly distributed.
{Very_poorly_sorted} Particles are very different sizes and very unevenly distributed.
{Well_sorted} Particles are roughly the same size and evenly distributed.

property.name: Soil Texture
property.description: The type of sediment, eg clay, silt, sand and loam. Use the Material Helper or a Soil Sediment diagram for assisance.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {No_Observation} No Observation. Use the Texture helper to prefil this.
{Sand} A sand has a loose gritty feel and does not stick together. Individual sand grains can be seen or felt. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Loamy_Sand} In a loamy sand particles barely stick together and a moulded piece of soil just holds its shape. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Silty_Clay_Loam} A silty clay loam is like a clay loam but silty as well and smooth to the touch. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Clay_Loam} More easily moulded into a shape than a loam a clay loam rolls out to a thin ribbon between the palms while a loam will break-up. When dry a clay loam will form a lump but is not as tough to break as a clay.(VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Sandy_Clay_Loam} A sandy clay loam is like a clay loam but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam) (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Silt_Loam} A silty loam is like a loam but has a smooth silky feel when a moist sample is pushed between the index finger and thumb. On drying a sample can form a hard lump but this may be broken by hand. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Loam} A loam breaks into crumbs but will tend to stick together. Sand grains cannot be felt in a moist sample which when squeezed will retain its shape when handled freely. Loams are usually soft to the feel. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Sandy_Loam} A sandy loam sticks together more than a loamy sand but can be easily broken. Individual sand grains can be felt and heard if a wet sample is rubbed between the index finger and thumb and held close to the ear. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Silty_Clay} A silty clay is like a clay but smoother. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

{Clay} Clays are tough and can be moulded into shapes when moist. Clays form a long flexible ribbon when rubbed between the palms and the ribbon can often be bent into a U shape without breaking. Clays dry into very hard clods. (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)
{Sandy_Clay} A sandy clay is like a clay but sand grains can be felt (and heard - see Sandy Loam). (VDEPI 2009: AG0058)

property.name: Soil Colour
property.description: Broad colour description of the soil, eg 'mid greyish brown'.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Heterogeneous} Deposit with different mixed components which need to be described.
{Laminated} Laminated Deposit consists of lots of fine lenses of the same material. Compact laminated Deposit consists of a number of fine lenses of different materials.
{Compact_Laminated} Deposit consists of a number of fine lenses of different materials

property.name: Skeleton Condition
property.description: Describe the general condition of the skeleton and any comments on articulation. Any degeneration of bone in situ is important to record as well as accidental damage during excavation and lifting. Record disturbances through later activity or animal/root activity as well as damage due to stone pressure on the bones. It is important to note whether the patellae, hyoid, phalanges, basi-occipital etc are present or not, and their location, as this may give an indication of the state of the body at the time of interment.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Negative_Element} Any Context which forms a negative interface (cut) with another context, such as a cut for a pit, burial, ditch, wall foundation or robber trench.
{Deposit} Any Context with deposited sediment and soil, such as floor layers, pit and grave fills, hearth fills and natural sediments.
{Structure} Any Context consisting of deliberately constructed structures, independent of a Negative Element (i.e. cut, such as walls and hearths).
{Wall} A structured vertical barrier made from durable materials defining a space.
{Floor} A prepared surface, internal or external, including those made from plaster, earth etc.
{Well} A deep pit excavated to reach the water table.
{Pit} A large cut filled with sediment or other materials.
{Room} A discrete space within a house or other building.
{Burial} The cut, fill plus any associated structures relating to the deposition of human remains, including those remains, such as a skeleton.
{Building} A building is defined when several walls surround a discrete space
{Surface} A compacted horizontal layer, internal or external, on which activities took place.
{Space} A space is an area bounded by a structure of some kind, either external or internal, and can be for example a courtyard, room, ante-room etc.
{Posthole} A small pit cut to hold an upright post.
{Stakehole} Cuts smaller than postholes, typically c. 1-5 cm diameter.
{Hearth} A prepared structure in which a fire is set.
{Stakehole_row} A row of cuts smaller than postholes, typically c. 1-5 cm diameter.
{Other} Function not elsewhere described. Provide details in Annotation field.

property.name: Component
property.description: Describe the components which make up 10% or more of the deposit.

lookup.term: {Midden} Organic debris e.g. bones carbonised material phytoliths etc
{Mudbrick} Fragments of mudbrick or whole mudbricks not part of a coherent structural element.
{Ash} White/grey fine material which may contain charcoal and other burnt plant material.
{Artefacts} Human manufactured materials including lithics, beads, ground stone etc.

lookup.term: {Dressed_Stone} Those that have been clearly shaped for use.
{Tabular} Stones with flattened upper and lower surfaces.
{Ground} Stones that have been deliberately shaped smooth by grinding.

ArchaeologicalElement.name: Sample
ArchaeologicalElement.description: Deposit samples or samples of building elements recovered from this Context for the purpose of further analysis or ongoing reference.

property.name: Context ID
property.description: Unique number or code for the Context from which this Artefact Cluster was collected.
property.formatString: Cxtx-$2-

property.name: Sample ID
property.description: The unique code or reference for the Sample. This should be assigned with reference to the central register
property.formatString: Sample-$2-

property.name: Sample Type
property.description: The type of Sample collected as detailed below.

lookup.term: {Building_Materials} Sample of bricks or worked stone collected from this Context.
{Soil} General collection of soil deposit from the Context.
{Wood_Charcoal} Collection of wood or charcoal fragments from the Context.
{C14_Sample} An organic sample recovered for radiocarbon dating.
{Flot_Sample} Flotation sample for recovery of plant remains.
{Phytolith_Sample} Small soil sample for phytolith analysis.
{Thin_Section} Specially collected blocks for soil thin sectioning.
{Animal_Bone} A sample of bone identified as animal.
{Human_Bone} A sample of bone identified as human.
{Other} Sample not elsewhere described. Include details in Annotation field.

property.name: Sample Volume
property.description: Volume (in litres) of the sample collected.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Sample X
property.description: The reading from the x-axis (horizontal) of an arbitrary site grid corresponding to the location of the Sample at the time of excavation.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Sample Y
property.description: The reading from the y-axis (vertical) of an arbitrary site grid corresponding to the location of the Sample at the time of excavation.
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Sample Z
